subject: Re: [junit] JavaBeans specs clarification needed
msgSnippet: How does returning the value set simplify the tests? public void testSetFoo() throws Exception { assertEquals( Foo , d_thingy.setFoo( Foo )); } is clearly not
messageBody:
How does returning the value set simplify the tests?

public void testSetFoo() throws Exception
{
assertEquals("Foo", d_thingy.setFoo("Foo"));
}

is clearly not valid, since:

public String setFoo(String value) {return value;}

will pass this test even though it makes no state change. But:

public void testSetFoo() throws Exception
{
d_thingy.setFoo("Foo");
assertEquals("Foo", d_thingy.getFoo());
}

works no matter what setFoo() returns.

On Wed, 10 Oct 2001, Thomas SMETS wrote:

>
> I'm currently working on a project where the core development is a set
> of JavaBeans implementing NeuralNetwork data analysis.
>
> I propose to implement the Unit tests but noted that the setXXX should
> return the value set to simplify the testing. Does the JavaBean Specs
> accept the setMethods() to return something else than "void" ?
>
> Tx for comments & remarks,
>
> Thomas,
